title: MWFRS Wind Pressure on Low-Rise Building
problem: A one-story commercial building is being designed for wind loads on the Main Wind Force Resisting System (MWFRS). The building is located in Dallas, Texas, and has a rectangular plan dimensions of 120 ft × 80 ft with a flat roof at an eave height of 24 ft. The building has a Risk Category II classification and is located in Exposure B with a topographic factor $K_{zt} = 1.0$. Determine the design wind pressure on the windward wall using the directional procedure.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 115$ mph (from ASCE 7-16 Figure 26.5-1A for Risk Category II)
Building dimensions: 120 ft × 80 ft plan, 24 ft eave height
required: Calculate the design wind pressure ($p$) on the windward wall at the mean roof height.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient $K_z$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure B at height $z = 24$ ft (mean roof height for flat roof):

$K_z = 0.70$ (interpolated between 0.57 at 15 ft and 0.70 at 30 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_z$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 26.10-1:

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

Where $K_d = 0.85$ (MWFRS, Table 26.6-1), $K_e = 1.0$ (sea level), $K_{zt} = 1.0$

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 0.70 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (115)^2$$

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 0.70 \times 0.85 \times 13,225 = 20.05 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Internal Pressure Coefficient $GC_{pi}$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.11-1, for enclosed building:

$$GC_{pi} = \pm 0.18$$

solution_steps.title: Determine External Pressure Coefficient $C_p$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Figure 27.3-1, for windward wall:

$L/B = 120/80 = 1.5$

For windward wall, $C_p = 0.8$ (constant with height per Figure 27.3-1 notes)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Wind Pressure $p$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 27.3-1:

$$p = q_z \times G \times C_p - q_i \times GC_{pi}$$

For rigid building, $G = 0.85$ (or calculate using Section 26.11).

Assuming $G = 0.85$.

For positive internal pressure (worst case for windward wall):

$$p = 20.05 \times 0.85 \times 0.8 - 20.05 \times 0.18$$

$$p = 13.63 - 3.61 = 10.02 \text{ psf}$$

For negative internal pressure:

$$p = 20.05 \times 0.85 \times 0.8 + 20.05 \times 0.18$$

$$p = 13.63 + 3.61 = 17.24 \text{ psf}$$

final_answer: The design wind pressure on the windward wall is $17.24$ psf (controlling case with negative internal pressure). This is the pressure that should be used for MWFRS design.

title: Components & Cladding Wind Pressure on Wall
problem: Determine the design wind pressure for Components and Cladding (C&C) on the wall of an enclosed office building. The building has a mean roof height of 35 ft, is located in Miami, Florida, with a Risk Category III classification. The wall panel under consideration has an effective wind area of 50 sq ft. Use Exposure C conditions.
given: Basic wind speed $V = 170$ mph (Miami, Risk Category III, ASCE 7-16 Figure 26.5-1B)
required: Calculate the design wind pressure for C&C on the wall panel at height $z = 35$ ft.

solution_steps.title: Determine Velocity Pressure Coefficient $K_z$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 26.10-1, for Exposure C at height $z = 35$ ft:

$$K_z = 1.01$$ (interpolated between 0.98 at 30 ft and 1.03 at 40 ft)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Velocity Pressure $q_h$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 26.10-1:

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$

Where $K_d = 0.85$ (C&C, Table 26.6-1), $K_e = 1.0$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 1.01 \times 1.0 \times 0.85 \times 1.0 \times (170)^2$$

$$q_h = 0.00256 \times 1.01 \times 0.85 \times 28,900 = 63.36 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine External Pressure Coefficients $GC_p$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Figure 30.3-1, for walls of enclosed buildings.

For effective wind area = 50 sq ft:

**Zone 4 (wall interior):**
- $GC_p(positive) = 0.91$
- $GC_p(negative) = -1.05$

**Zone 5 (wall edges/corners):**
- $GC_p(positive) = 0.91$
- $GC_p(negative) = -1.33$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Wind Pressure
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 30.3-1:

$$p = q_h \times (GC_p - GC_{pi})$$

For enclosed building, $GC_{pi} = \pm 0.18$

**For Zone 4 interior wall:**

$$p(positive \ external + negative \ internal) = 63.36 \times (0.91 - (-0.18))$$

$$= 63.36 \times 1.09 = 69.1 \text{ psf}$$

$$p(negative \ external + positive \ internal) = 63.36 \times (-1.05 - 0.18)$$

$$= 63.36 \times (-1.23) = -77.9 \text{ psf}$$

final_answer: The design wind pressures for C&C on the wall panel are $+69.1$ psf (positive/inward) and $-77.9$ psf (negative/outward). The controlling pressure for design is $77.9$ psf outward suction.

title: Seismic Base Shear for Reinforced Concrete Building
problem: A 5-story reinforced concrete special moment frame building is being designed in Los Angeles, California. The building has a total weight of 25,000 kips and a fundamental period of 0.85 seconds. The site is classified as Site Class D with mapped spectral accelerations $S_s = 1.85g$ and $S_1 = 0.65g$. Determine the seismic base shear using the equivalent lateral force procedure.
given: Building type: Reinforced concrete special moment frame
required: Calculate the seismic base shear $V$ using the equivalent lateral force procedure.

solution_steps.title: Determine Site Coefficients $F_a$ and $F_v$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Tables 11.4-1 and 11.4-2:

For Site Class D with $S_s = 1.85g$:
$$F_a = 1.0$$

For Site Class D with $S_1 = 0.65g$:
$$F_v = 1.5$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Adjusted Spectral Accelerations
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equations 11.4-1 and 11.4-2:

$$S_{MS} = F_a \times S_s = 1.0 \times 1.85 = 1.85g$$

$$S_{M1} = F_v \times S_1 = 1.5 \times 0.65 = 0.975g$$

Then, $S_{DS}$ and $S_{D1}$:

$$S_{DS} = \frac{2}{3} \times S_{MS} = \frac{2}{3} \times 1.85 = 1.23g$$

$$S_{D1} = \frac{2}{3} \times S_{M1} = \frac{2}{3} \times 0.975 = 0.65g$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Response Modification Factor $R$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 12.2-1, for reinforced concrete special moment frame (Type C1):

$$R = 8, \quad \Omega_0 = 3, \quad C_d = 5.5$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Seismic Response Coefficient $C_s$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 12.8-2:

$$C_s = \frac{S_{DS}}{R/I_e}$$

For Risk Category II, $I_e = 1.0$

$$C_s = \frac{1.23}{8/1.0} = 0.154$$

**Check upper limit** from Equation 12.8-3:

$$C_s \leq \frac{S_{D1}}{T \times R/I_e} = \frac{0.65}{0.85 \times 8/1.0} = 0.096$$

**Controlling $C_s = 0.096$** (upper limit governs)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Seismic Base Shear $V$
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 12.8-1:

$$V = C_s \times W = 0.096 \times 25,000 \text{ kips} = 2,400 \text{ kips}$$

final_answer: The seismic base shear $V = 2,400$ kips. Note: The upper limit of $C_s$ governed because the building period $T = 0.85$ sec is less than $T_L$ (typically 8-12 seconds for most of California).

title: Vertical Distribution of Seismic Forces
problem: A 6-story steel building has a calculated seismic base shear of 450 kips. The story weights and heights are: Floor 1 (base): 0 kips at 0 ft; Floor 2: 600 kips at 15 ft; Floor 3: 580 kips at 28 ft; Floor 4: 560 kips at 41 ft; Floor 5: 550 kips at 54 ft; Floor 6 (roof): 400 kips at 67 ft. The fundamental period $T = 0.65$ seconds. Distribute the seismic forces to each floor level.
required: Calculate the seismic force at each floor level using the vertical distribution procedure.

solution_steps.title: Determine Exponent $k$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Section 12.8.3, the exponent $k$ depends on building period:

- For $T \leq 0.5$ sec: $k = 1.0$
- For $T \geq 2.5$ sec: $k = 2.0$
- For $0.5 < T < 2.5$ sec:

$$k = 1.0 + 0.5(T - 0.5) = 1.0 + 0.5(0.65 - 0.5) = 1.075$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Seismic Force at Each Floor
solution_steps.content:
$$F_x = C_{vx} \times V$$

- $F_2 = 35.1$ kips
- $F_3 = 67.1$ kips
- $F_4 = 98.1$ kips
- $F_5 = 130.1$ kips
- $F_6 = 119.7$ kips

Check: $\sum F_x = 450$ kips ✓

final_answer: Seismic forces at each floor level: $F_2 = 35.1$ kips, $F_3 = 67.1$ kips, $F_4 = 98.1$ kips, $F_5 = 130.1$ kips, $F_6 = 119.7$ kips. Total = 450 kips.

title: Flat Roof Snow Load Calculation
problem: Determine the design flat roof snow load for an office building located in Denver, Colorado. The building has a flat roof at an elevation of 5,500 feet. The roof is partially exposed, and the building is located in Terrain Category B. The building has a Risk Category II classification. The ground snow load from ASCE 7-16 Figure 7.2-1 is $p_g = 18$ psf.
required: Calculate the design flat roof snow load $p_f$.

solution_steps.title: Determine Exposure Factor $C_e$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-1, for Terrain Category B and partially exposed roof:

$$C_e = 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Thermal Factor $C_t$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-2, for heated structure:

$$C_t = 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Importance Factor $I_s$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 1.5-2, for Risk Category II:

$$I_s = 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Flat Roof Snow Load
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 7.3-1:

$$p_f = 0.7 \times C_e \times C_t \times I_s \times p_g$$

$$p_f = 0.7 \times 1.0 \times 1.0 \times 1.0 \times 18 = 12.6 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Snow Load
solution_steps.content:
Per ASCE 7-16 Section 7.3.4:

$$p_{f,min} = I_s \times p_g = 1.0 \times 18 = 18 \text{ psf}$$

Since $p_f = 12.6$ psf $< p_{f,min} = 18$ psf, use $p_f = 18$ psf.

final_answer: The design flat roof snow load is $p_f = 18$ psf (minimum snow load governs).

title: Load Combinations for Beam Design
problem: A simply supported floor beam has the following service loads: Dead load = 2.5 kip/ft, Live load = 3.0 kip/ft, Roof live load = 1.2 kip/ft, Snow load = 1.5 kip/ft. Determine the factored load for LRFD design and the allowable stress design load. The beam spans 24 feet.
required: Determine the controlling factored load for LRFD and ASD.

solution_steps.title: Identify Applicable Loads
solution_steps.content:
Floor live load $L$ and roof live load $L_r$ are independent and should not be combined simultaneously in the same load combination according to ASCE 7-16 Section 2.3.2.

For this problem, we check combinations for:
- Floor beam: $D + L$
- Roof load contribution: $D + S$ or $D + L_r$

final_answer: Controlling LRFD factored load: $w_u = 8.55$ kip/ft. Controlling ASD load: $w_a = 5.88$ kip/ft. The LRFD combination with floor live load governs.
